575: <|endoftext|>New Orleans: A Supreme Court Justice has penned a dissent in an intriguing case regarding the Constitutionality of Louisiana's ban on "religious freedom" schools
576: Francis Brown, Chief Justice of the Louisiana Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, authored a plurality opinion for the Justices, which was greeted with a roar of approval in the local press
577: Here are the key findings from the opinion:"What this Court finds deeply troubling is the growing trend toward a narrow interpretation of the Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution, a plain and unambiguous right to exercise one's personal beliefs in religious beliefs
578: This Court's dissent has long been a natural fit for the Court to come to a decisive decision on the issue of how to interpret the Constitution
579: As the Ninth Circuit has had repeatedly said, there is no need to revisit this issue in light of the essential distinction between religious freedom and personal liberty, nor to explore the extent to which the central holding in Louisiana's First Amendment rights encompasses the Establishment Clause
580: ""As many Louisiana families have made clear, the statute providing for the exclusion of religious activity by certain colleges and universities from any public school district should not be interpreted to restrict the freedom of school speech and religion
581: Instead, the statute will be used to control the behavior of students and institutions by prohibiting both [those students and institutions] and by other State governments from infringing the exercise of religious rights
582: ""The Code of Civil Procedure provides that "[o]n fall of any university district, religious school, or society shall be subject to all the consequences of having the rule of law abrogated, or failing to apply it, must be dismissed from public schools
583: ""There is no cause of action for a particular public or political subdivision of a state over the acts, beliefs, or practices of the school district and any of its administrators
